newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian Broadcasting Corp Afternoon Update.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian Broadcasting Corp Afternoon Update.

text.p: CALLS FOR HEALTH MINISTER TO DENOUNCE CARE OVERHAUL
The Australian Doctors' Fund has called on Federal Health minister Michael Wooldridge to denounce plans by private health insurers to overhaul patient care.
Executive director Stephen Milgate says it would result in health funds dictating medical treatment to patients and GP's paid incentives to ration treatment.
Private insurers want an end to all restrictions which prevent funds from entering into financial agreements with doctors and hospitals.
The funds argue they can, on behalf of their members, act as informed and active buyers of health services.
The doctors' group says in the United States managed health care companies have made astonishing profits by rationing health care and creaming the profits.
Mr Milgate says the U-S system is evil, denying treatment to the sick.
ARSON SQUAD LOOKING FOR MOTORCYCLIST
In Victoria's Dandenong Ranges, Arson Squad detectives are continuing the search for those responsible for lighting last week's fatal bushfires.
Police have added a motorcyclist to the list of people they want to interview about the fires.
They're looking for the driver of a green 125 cc Kawasaki motorbike, seen driving in One tree Hill Road at Tremont near where three people were trapped and killed by fire.
A police caravan will be open at The Basin until Sunday for people to come forward with any information.
Detectives are also trying to track down three other vehicles seen in areas where the fires were started.
GOVERNMENT DEFENDS ACTION AGAINST VOYAGER VICTIM
The Federal Government has defended its High Court action against a man involved in the Voyager disaster by claiming it's trying to maintain consistency.
The Commonwealth is seeking leave to appeal against the extension of time granted to William McLean, who's currently facing the second Supreme Court trial of his compensation case.
Federal Attorney General Darryl Williams says the Commonwealth is going to the High Court so it can maintain a consistant approach to Voyager compensation claims.
But Mr McLean's lawyer, James Taylor, is unconvinced.
INSECT-BASED DRUG RESEARCH
Australian Pharmaceutical company, Bio-Discovery Limited, is planning to take advantage of Australia's huge insect population to develop new drugs.
The company is joining forces with other research institutions, including the CSIRO, to develop new drugs to fight diseases such as alzheimer's and diabetes.
The CSIRO's John Okeshott says Australia's an ideal place to experiment with insect-based drugs because it has more than 200-thousand species, the majority of which are unique to Australia.
SUPPORT FOR PRIVATELY-RUN PUBLIC HOSPITALS
An international credit rating agency has given strong support to the expansion of privately-run public hospitals in Australia.
Standard and Poors has given an A-minus long-term credit rating to bonds, which will be issued to fund Victoria's Latrobe Regional Hospital.
The hospital will be privately built and run at East Morwell, with its public services being sold to the Victorian Government.
Standard and Poors says it regards the project as a landmark, in what's likely to be a key business growth area.
However, it says the need to cut costs, and the chance of changes in Government health policy, are key risks to the Latrobe project.
The agency says the private company, L-R-H, will have to run the hospital more efficiently than the public sector, to make a profit.
PASQUARELLI WANTS FAIR-GO
John Pasquarelli, the ex-senior advisor to the Independant Queensland MP, Pauline Hanson, has entered the Industrial Relations Commission in Melbourne, saying he wants a fair go from his former boss.
The MP's former staffer was dismissed in December, amid what he claims was a power struggle over management and policy direction.
The case is currently before the IRC to determine whether Mr Pasquarelli was unlawfully dismissed.
MANSFIELD'S MATHS DOES NOT ADD UP, ABC UNION MEETING TOLD
Meetings of ABC union members around Australia have voted on resolutions criticising sections of the Mansfield review into the future of the ABC.
Public Service Union members heard that regardless of the outcome of the review, the ABC continues to face a 12 per cent cut in funding, threatening programming and broadcasting.
Resolutions condemned recommendations of the review to contract out television production and for the ABC to abandon international broadcasting.
